values.description:
There is an issue that a light is not rendered when a model which holds the light is spawned. It was found that a message being published to `~/model/info` does not have the light information.

Thanks to the help by @iche033 , this PR fixes this issue by publishing a correct message.

The testing code `LightFactoryTest.SpawnModelWithLight` in `INTEGRATION_factory` spawns a simple model with a light, and compares a message for `~/model/info`, which is listened by the rendering engine, and the entity information, which the physics engine actually has.

‌

---

Here are some details.

When a model is being spawned, the process goes in the following order:

1. Load
2. FillMsg
3. Publish ->`` `~/model/info``
4. Init

FillMsg \(# 2\) looks up the list of light objects in a link object. However, the light objects are added to the list at # 4. So the message sent to `~/model/info` does not contain the light information.

This PR moves the line of adding the lights from # 4 to # 1, so the FillMsg can see the light objects to include in a message.
values.title: Fix for the spawning light issue

summary.raw:
There is an issue that a light is not rendered when a model which holds the light is spawned. It was found that a message being published to `~/model/info` does not have the light information.

Thanks to the help by @iche033 , this PR fixes this issue by publishing a correct message.

The testing code `LightFactoryTest.SpawnModelWithLight` in `INTEGRATION_factory` spawns a simple model with a light, and compares a message for `~/model/info`, which is listened by the rendering engine, and the entity information, which the physics engine actually has.

‌

---

Here are some details.

When a model is being spawned, the process goes in the following order:

1. Load
2. FillMsg
3. Publish ->`` `~/model/info``
4. Init

FillMsg \(# 2\) looks up the list of light objects in a link object. However, the light objects are added to the list at # 4. So the message sent to `~/model/info` does not contain the light information.

This PR moves the line of adding the lights from # 4 to # 1, so the FillMsg can see the light objects to include in a message.
summary.html:
There is an issue that a light is not rendered when a model which holds the light is spawned. It was found that a message being published to ~/model/info does not have the light information.

Thanks to the help by @iche033 , this PR fixes this issue by publishing a correct message.

The testing code LightFactoryTest.SpawnModelWithLight in INTEGRATION_factory spawns a simple model with a light, and compares a message for ~/model/info, which is listened by the rendering engine, and the entity information, which the physics engine actually has.

‌

Here are some details.

When a model is being spawned, the process goes in the following order:

  1. Load
  2. FillMsg
  3. Publish ->`~/model/info
  4. Init

FillMsg (# 2) looks up the list of light objects in a link object. However, the light objects are added to the list at # 4. So the message sent to ~/model/info does not contain the light information.

This PR moves the line of adding the lights from # 4 to # 1, so the FillMsg can see the light objects to include in a message.

values.description:
Modified the current collision feature of Gazebo, to add bounding collision shapes to selected single-visual models. These bounding collisions are primitive shapes namely box, sphere and cylinder.

Comments \(WIP\):

* Takes care of different scales and sizes of visual.
* Existing issues in model editor prevents addition of a second bounding shape and variation in visual pose.
values.title: [WIP] Outreachy bounding collision shapes

summary.raw:
Modified the current collision feature of Gazebo, to add bounding collision shapes to selected single-visual models. These bounding collisions are primitive shapes namely box, sphere and cylinder.

Comments \(WIP\):

* Takes care of different scales and sizes of visual.
* Existing issues in model editor prevents addition of a second bounding shape and variation in visual pose.
summary.html:
Modified the current collision feature of Gazebo, to add bounding collision shapes to selected single-visual models. These bounding collisions are primitive shapes namely box, sphere and cylinder.

Comments (WIP):

  • Takes care of different scales and sizes of visual.
  • Existing issues in model editor prevents addition of a second bounding shape and variation in visual pose.

values.description:
This fixes issue #2505.

* [92c8748](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/92c8748187e598ebf50449888082453c7cefbc40) creates a regression test. Run the test on this commit to see the bug get triggered
* [94823a5](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/94823a5ab0eaf9900bdbf6e1b5d8531152ed7aed) adds the fix for the bug, which is just removing a few lines

Additionally, in [b7c10ad](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/b7c10ad60c25a0fdb780dcf28c534df43a42035e) I enabled some old tests for DART that should be working in this version of Gazebo.
values.title: Fix for issue 2505 -- DARTHingJoint::SetAxis

* [92c8748](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/92c8748187e598ebf50449888082453c7cefbc40) creates a regression test. Run the test on this commit to see the bug get triggered
* [94823a5](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/94823a5ab0eaf9900bdbf6e1b5d8531152ed7aed) adds the fix for the bug, which is just removing a few lines

Additionally, in [b7c10ad](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/b7c10ad60c25a0fdb780dcf28c534df43a42035e) I enabled some old tests for DART that should be working in this version of Gazebo.

This fixes issue #2505.

  • 92c8748 creates a regression test. Run the test on this commit to see the bug get triggered
  • 94823a5 adds the fix for the bug, which is just removing a few lines

Additionally, in b7c10ad I enabled some old tests for DART that should be working in this version of Gazebo.

values.description: We recently merged pull request #2797 without addressing some of the comments in that pull request about whether the variable names should be made consistent. This renames some log message fields from `save_model` to `record_resources` to match the changes made in pull request #2811.
values.title: Rename log msg field save_model to record_resources

summary.raw: We recently merged pull request #2797 without addressing some of the comments in that pull request about whether the variable names should be made consistent. This renames some log message fields from `save_model` to `record_resources` to match the changes made in pull request #2811.
summary.html: We recently merged pull request #2797 without addressing some of the comments in that pull request about whether the variable names should be made consistent. This renames some log message fields from save_model to record_resources to match the changes made in pull request #2811.

values.description:
Without this, the first interface selected might not be active, and it leads to a silent failure and a black render window in gzclient. It appears to occur commonly when running Gazebo under the Windows Subsystem for Linux.

For more info, see this WSL issue: [https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368](https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368)
values.title: Adding check to make sure automatic interface selection only uses interfaces that are up.

summary.raw:
Without this, the first interface selected might not be active, and it leads to a silent failure and a black render window in gzclient. It appears to occur commonly when running Gazebo under the Windows Subsystem for Linux.

For more info, see this WSL issue: [https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368](https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368)
summary.html:
Without this, the first interface selected might not be active, and it leads to a silent failure and a black render window in gzclient. It appears to occur commonly when running Gazebo under the Windows Subsystem for Linux.

For more info, see this WSL issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3368

values.description:
This pull request addresses a problem in the fixed joint implementation in bullet that causes an unexpected rotation when a fixed joints is used with links that have inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal. As the gif demonstrates, the box rotates about 45 degrees as soon as the simulation starts. This doesn’t happen when using any other physics engine.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/GgE7oqx/images/1976104576-fixed_joint_off_diagonal.gif)
‌

This PR replaces the use of `btHingeConstraint` with `btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint` although it’s not clear why the `btHingeConstraint` wasn’t working in the first place.

## Update:

I ended up reverting back to using `btHingeConstraint`. It’s a much simpler fix this way. The initial offset had to be used for the joint limit constraints.
values.title: Bullet: Fixed joints and inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal

summary.raw:
This pull request addresses a problem in the fixed joint implementation in bullet that causes an unexpected rotation when a fixed joints is used with links that have inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal. As the gif demonstrates, the box rotates about 45 degrees as soon as the simulation starts. This doesn’t happen when using any other physics engine.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/GgE7oqx/images/1976104576-fixed_joint_off_diagonal.gif)
‌

This PR replaces the use of `btHingeConstraint` with `btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint` although it’s not clear why the `btHingeConstraint` wasn’t working in the first place.

## Update:

I ended up reverting back to using `btHingeConstraint`. It’s a much simpler fix this way. The initial offset had to be used for the joint limit constraints.
summary.html:
This pull request addresses a problem in the fixed joint implementation in bullet that causes an unexpected rotation when a fixed joints is used with links that have inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal. As the gif demonstrates, the box rotates about 45 degrees as soon as the simulation starts. This doesn’t happen when using any other physics engine.

‌

This PR replaces the use of btHingeConstraint with btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint although it’s not clear why the btHingeConstraint wasn’t working in the first place.

Update:

I ended up reverting back to using btHingeConstraint. It’s a much simpler fix this way. The initial offset had to be used for the joint limit constraints.

values.description:
It's there on `gazebo7`, so it was removed at some point.

This prevents downstream errors like:

~~~
In file included from /home/developer/gazebo_ros_pkgs/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_camera.cpp:16:0:
/usr/include/gazebo-9/gazebo/rendering/Distortion.hh:49:33: error: 'sdf' has not been declared
       public: virtual void Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf);
                                 ^~~
/usr/include/gazebo-9/gazebo/rendering/Distortion.hh:49:49: error: expected ',' or '...' before '_s$f'
       public: virtual void Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf);
~~~

Should be ported forward to `gazebo9` and `default`.
values.title: Include SDF in rendering::Distortion

values.description:
Reads the `tension` parameter from [this SDF PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/466/tension/diff), and passes it along to ignition math.

The tension parameter allows the user to control how strictly the animation should follow the set of waypoints.

You can see the difference by running `tension.world`: gazebo worlds/tension.world
values.title: Use tension trajectory parameter

summary.raw:
Reads the `tension` parameter from [this SDF PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/466/tension/diff), and passes it along to ignition math.

The tension parameter allows the user to control how strictly the animation should follow the set of waypoints.

You can see the difference by running `tension.world`: gazebo worlds/tension.world
summary.html:
Reads the tension parameter from this SDF PR, and passes it along to ignition math.

The tension parameter allows the user to control how strictly the animation should follow the set of waypoints.

You can see the difference by running tension.world: gazebo worlds/tension.world

values.description:
A couple of fixes in this PR:

Currently a visual plugin is loaded only when a visual is first created. However, sometimes a visual msg with an empty plugin field could be received on the `~/visual` topic before the full scene msg on gzclient startup. This would create a visual without a plugin even if a visual plugin is specified in the SDF. This PR makes sure that we always check the the visual msg’s plugin field on update and load the plugins if not done so already.

‌

Another fix included in this PR is the renaming of light visuals that we create internally for light visualization \(changes in Light.cc\). This is mainly to to avoid name conflicts with user specified visuals in the SDF, e.g. the FlashLight plugin expects users to create a <light> and <visual> with the same name. **Update**: reverted this change as it broke tests
values.title: Check and load visual plugins on update

summary.raw:
A couple of fixes in this PR:

Currently a visual plugin is loaded only when a visual is first created. However, sometimes a visual msg with an empty plugin field could be received on the `~/visual` topic before the full scene msg on gzclient startup. This would create a visual without a plugin even if a visual plugin is specified in the SDF. This PR makes sure that we always check the the visual msg’s plugin field on update and load the plugins if not done so already.

‌

Another fix included in this PR is the renaming of light visuals that we create internally for light visualization \(changes in Light.cc\). This is mainly to to avoid name conflicts with user specified visuals in the SDF, e.g. the FlashLight plugin expects users to create a <light> and <visual> with the same name. **Update**: reverted this change as it broke tests
summary.html:
A couple of fixes in this PR:

Currently a visual plugin is loaded only when a visual is first created. However, sometimes a visual msg with an empty plugin field could be received on the ~/visual topic before the full scene msg on gzclient startup. This would create a visual without a plugin even if a visual plugin is specified in the SDF. This PR makes sure that we always check the the visual msg’s plugin field on update and load the plugins if not done so already.

‌

Another fix included in this PR is the renaming of light visuals that we create internally for light visualization (changes in Light.cc). This is mainly to to avoid name conflicts with user specified visuals in the SDF, e.g. the FlashLight plugin expects users to create a <light> and <visual> with the same name. Update: reverted this change as it broke tests

values.description:
If the `INTEGRATION_static_map_plugin` test gets interrupted before it deletes its temporary folder, future invocations of the test will fail with the following console output:

~~~
[ RUN      ] StaticMapTest.StaticMapPlugin
unknown file: Failure
C++ exception with description "boost::filesystem::rename: Directory not empty: "/home/scpeters/.gazebo/models/map_satellite_37.386491_-122.065255_100_100", "/home/scpeters/.gazebo/models/map_satellite_37.386491_-122.065255_100_100_bk"" thrown in the test body.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:135] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] StaticMapTest.StaticMapPlugin (1 ms)
~~~

This can be fixed by removing the backup folder before performing the rename operation.
values.title: static_map_plugin.cc: remove backup folder

summary.raw:
If the `INTEGRATION_static_map_plugin` test gets interrupted before it deletes its temporary folder, future invocations of the test will fail with the following console output:

~~~
[ RUN      ] StaticMapTest.StaticMapPlugin
unknown file: Failure
C++ exception with description "boost::filesystem::rename: Directory not empty: "/home/scpeters/.gazebo/models/map_satellite_37.386491_-122.065255_100_100", "/home/scpeters/.gazebo/models/map_satellite_37.386491_-122.065255_100_100_bk"" thrown in the test body.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:135] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] StaticMapTest.StaticMapPlugin (1 ms)
~~~

This can be fixed by removing the backup folder before performing the rename operation.
summary.html:
If the INTEGRATION_static_map_plugin test gets interrupted before it deletes its temporary folder, future invocations of the test will fail with the following console output:

[ RUN      ] StaticMapTest.StaticMapPlugin
unknown file: Failure
C++ exception with description "boost::filesystem::rename: Directory not empty: "/home/scpeters/.gazebo/models/map_satellite_37.386491_-122.065255_100_100", "/home/scpeters/.gazebo/models/map_satellite_37.386491_-122.065255_100_100_bk"" thrown in the test body.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:135] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] StaticMapTest.StaticMapPlugin (1 ms)

This can be fixed by removing the backup folder before performing the rename operation.

values.description:
Our version of ODE doesn't implement `dJointGetHinge2Angle2`. In the past, the function `ODEHinge2Joint::PositionImpl` returned 0 for the angle of the second axis. The regression occurred in 03b7ba1 because we started returning NAN instead.

A regression test for issue #2239 is added in a5680ed. The test simply spawns a revolute2 joint and checks if the position of the link attached to the joint moves to the origin after one simulation step.

a5680ed fixes the issue.  This fix involves an update to ode from https://bitbucket.org/odedevs/ode/commits/b3ac898a53cf to get the `dJointGetHinge2Angle2` function and return that angle instead of NAN.

cc: @sloretz
values.title: Fix Issue 2239: All links teleport to origin if model has a revolute2 joint.

summary.raw:
Our version of ODE doesn't implement `dJointGetHinge2Angle2`. In the past, the function `ODEHinge2Joint::PositionImpl` returned 0 for the angle of the second axis. The regression occurred in 03b7ba1 because we started returning NAN instead.

A regression test for issue #2239 is added in a5680ed. The test simply spawns a revolute2 joint and checks if the position of the link attached to the joint moves to the origin after one simulation step.

a5680ed fixes the issue.  This fix involves an update to ode from https://bitbucket.org/odedevs/ode/commits/b3ac898a53cf to get the `dJointGetHinge2Angle2` function and return that angle instead of NAN.

cc: @sloretz
summary.html:
Our version of ODE doesn't implement dJointGetHinge2Angle2. In the past, the function ODEHinge2Joint::PositionImpl returned 0 for the angle of the second axis. The regression occurred in 03b7ba1 because we started returning NAN instead.

A regression test for issue #2239 is added in a5680ed. The test simply spawns a revolute2 joint and checks if the position of the link attached to the joint moves to the origin after one simulation step.

a5680ed fixes the issue. This fix involves an update to ode from https://bitbucket.org/odedevs/ode/commits/b3ac898a53cf to get the dJointGetHinge2Angle2 function and return that angle instead of NAN.

cc: @sloretz

values.description:
Related issue #2546

I just set  skyx to use an empty material in the ssao compositor pass. There maybe a cleaner way to solving this problem like using visibility flags / masks for skyx in general but for a plugin I think this workaround is fine.

Here's a screenshot of the `ssao_plugin.world` with sky enabled

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3122497398-skyx_ssao.png)
values.title: Skip skyx in SSAO plugin

summary.raw:
Related issue #2546

I just set  skyx to use an empty material in the ssao compositor pass. There maybe a cleaner way to solving this problem like using visibility flags / masks for skyx in general but for a plugin I think this workaround is fine.

Here's a screenshot of the `ssao_plugin.world` with sky enabled

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3122497398-skyx_ssao.png)
summary.html:
Related issue #2546

I just set skyx to use an empty material in the ssao compositor pass. There maybe a cleaner way to solving this problem like using visibility flags / masks for skyx in general but for a plugin I think this workaround is fine.

Here's a screenshot of the ssao_plugin.world with sky enabled

values.description:
Homebrew is now using boost 1.68. In [boost 1.66](https://www.boost.org/users/history/version_1_66_0.html), the `boost/uuid/sha1.hpp` header file was moved to a `detail` subfolder, with a temporary placeholder to allow for migration. I never saw any compiler warnings, so I didn't know about the deprecation, but now we know, since the header file was removed in boost 1.68.

Failure first spotted here:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64&build=125)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/125/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/125/
values.title: Use new sha1.hpp header location for recent boost

summary.raw:
Homebrew is now using boost 1.68. In [boost 1.66](https://www.boost.org/users/history/version_1_66_0.html), the `boost/uuid/sha1.hpp` header file was moved to a `detail` subfolder, with a temporary placeholder to allow for migration. I never saw any compiler warnings, so I didn't know about the deprecation, but now we know, since the header file was removed in boost 1.68.

Failure first spotted here:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64&build=125)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/125/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/125/
summary.html:
Homebrew is now using boost 1.68. In boost 1.66, the boost/uuid/sha1.hpp header file was moved to a detail subfolder, with a temporary placeholder to allow for migration. I never saw any compiler warnings, so I didn't know about the deprecation, but now we know, since the header file was removed in boost 1.68.

Failure first spotted here:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/125/

values.description: * use new sha1.hpp header location for recent boost
values.title: Merge 7 -> 8 (boost 1.68 support)

summary.raw: * use new sha1.hpp header location for recent boost
summary.html: • use new sha1.hpp header location for recent boost

values.description:
Backport pull request #2751 based on discussion in #2555.

Original description by @pchorak :

This PR introduces a model plugin that loads joint controller parameters from a world file (sdf). This functionality was proposed in issue #1766. The PR includes an example world file using the double pendulum model.

values.description:
This pull request makes it possible to set the sonar collision shape.

It also writes the closest contact position in sonar message to display a red ray going from the reference point to the closest contact point.

values.description:
Addresses #2541.

It looks like any class that includes `gazebo/gui/gui.hh` will end up needing `QTest` symbols. See a plugin for example:

~~~
developer@2acf1ecf5fc2:~/gazebo$ nm -g /usr/local/lib/gazebo-9/plugins/libKeyboardGUIPlugin.so  | grep QTest
                 U _ZN5QTest15defaultKeyDelayEv@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest15lastMouseButtonE@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest17defaultMouseDelayEv@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest18lastMouseTimestampE@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest5qWarnEPKcS1_i@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest6qSleepEi@@Qt_5
~~~

And then if you don't link against QTest libraries, the plugin will fail to run.

I think the long-term solution would be for `QTest` headers to be removed from `gazebo/gui/gui.hh`. But removing them in a release branch may break user code, so I'll make a PR to `default`.

Alternative solutions are to:

1. Link against `${Qt5Test_LIBRARIES}`
1. Don't include `gazebo/gui/gui.hh`

This PR changes all built-in plugins and example plugins to do option 2 and don't include that big header. I'm personally not a fan of these large includes anyway.
values.title: Fix GUI plugins on Bionic + gz9

Addresses #2541.

It looks like any class that includes `gazebo/gui/gui.hh` will end up needing `QTest` symbols. See a plugin for example:

~~~
developer@2acf1ecf5fc2:~/gazebo$ nm -g /usr/local/lib/gazebo-9/plugins/libKeyboardGUIPlugin.so  | grep QTest
                 U _ZN5QTest15defaultKeyDelayEv@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest15lastMouseButtonE@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest17defaultMouseDelayEv@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest18lastMouseTimestampE@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest5qWarnEPKcS1_i@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest6qSleepEi@@Qt_5
~~~

And then if you don't link against QTest libraries, the plugin will fail to run.

I think the long-term solution would be for `QTest` headers to be removed from `gazebo/gui/gui.hh`. But removing them in a release branch may break user code, so I'll make a PR to `default`.

Alternative solutions are to:

1. Link against `${Qt5Test_LIBRARIES}`
1. Don't include `gazebo/gui/gui.hh`

This PR changes all built-in plugins and example plugins to do option 2 and don't include that big header. I'm personally not a fan of these large includes anyway.
summary.html:
Addresses #2541.

It looks like any class that includes gazebo/gui/gui.hh will end up needing QTest symbols. See a plugin for example:

developer@2acf1ecf5fc2:~/gazebo$ nm -g /usr/local/lib/gazebo-9/plugins/libKeyboardGUIPlugin.so  | grep QTest
                 U _ZN5QTest15defaultKeyDelayEv@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest15lastMouseButtonE@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest17defaultMouseDelayEv@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest18lastMouseTimestampE@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest5qWarnEPKcS1_i@@Qt_5
                 U _ZN5QTest6qSleepEi@@Qt_5

And then if you don't link against QTest libraries, the plugin will fail to run.

I think the long-term solution would be for QTest headers to be removed from gazebo/gui/gui.hh. But removing them in a release branch may break user code, so I'll make a PR to default.

Alternative solutions are to:

  1. Link against ${Qt5Test_LIBRARIES}
  2. Don't include gazebo/gui/gui.hh

This PR changes all built-in plugins and example plugins to do option 2 and don't include that big header. I'm personally not a fan of these large includes anyway.

values.description:
issue #2572

The fix ensures that the terrain is fully loaded before attempting to save the cache file. The problem seems to affect only ubuntu bionic \+ ogre 1.9 and not xenial. This fixes the  `HeightmapTest.HeightmapCache` test for me  \(`test/integration/heightmap.cc`\)

Jenkins does not catch this test failure as there are no gazebo bionic-gpu jobs.

values.description:
I recently attempted to extend the ODE Gearbox joint to allow the gear ratio to be adjusted dynamically, but the gearbox joint implementation wasn't behaving the way I expected. I was expecting it to behave like the [ODE hinge joint implementation](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0110572a49ba08936c9ac1972771db391b5ab721/deps/opende/src/joints/hinge.cpp?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#hinge.cpp-67:73), which calls the [helper function getHingeAngle](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0110572a49ba08936c9ac1972771db391b5ab721/deps/opende/src/joints/joint.cpp?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#joint.cpp-433:443) with arguments: (child body, parent body, joint axis in body-fixed frame, initial relative rotation between 
bodies). By contrast, the gearbox joint had reversed the order of the bodies (reference body then child body), computed the joint axis in a global frame, and re-computed the relative body rotation (by calling `dJointSetGearboxReferenceBody[12]`) at each time step.

So this refactoring does the following:

* Don't update relative rotations `qrel[12]` by calling `dJointSetGearboxReferenceBody[12]` at each timestep
* Use body-fixed axis, not global
* Reverse angle direction by switching relative bodies. This required reversing some arguments in other rotation calculations elsewhere in the file.

This should be a pure refactoring that doesn't change any behavior, but it will set the stage for an extension to this joint that I'd like to make. There is a gearbox joint test, and I've verified locally that it passes; hopefully CI agrees.
values.title: Refactor ode gearbox math to more closely match ode hinge math

summary.raw:
I recently attempted to extend the ODE Gearbox joint to allow the gear ratio to be adjusted dynamically, but the gearbox joint implementation wasn't behaving the way I expected. I was expecting it to behave like the [ODE hinge joint implementation](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0110572a49ba08936c9ac1972771db391b5ab721/deps/opende/src/joints/hinge.cpp?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#hinge.cpp-67:73), which calls the [helper function getHingeAngle](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0110572a49ba08936c9ac1972771db391b5ab721/deps/opende/src/joints/joint.cpp?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#joint.cpp-433:443) with arguments: (child body, parent body, joint axis in body-fixed frame, initial relative rotation between 
bodies). By contrast, the gearbox joint had reversed the order of the bodies (reference body then child body), computed the joint axis in a global frame, and re-computed the relative body rotation (by calling `dJointSetGearboxReferenceBody[12]`) at each time step.

So this refactoring does the following:

* Don't update relative rotations `qrel[12]` by calling `dJointSetGearboxReferenceBody[12]` at each timestep
* Use body-fixed axis, not global
* Reverse angle direction by switching relative bodies. This required reversing some arguments in other rotation calculations elsewhere in the file.

This should be a pure refactoring that doesn't change any behavior, but it will set the stage for an extension to this joint that I'd like to make. There is a gearbox joint test, and I've verified locally that it passes; hopefully CI agrees.
summary.html:
I recently attempted to extend the ODE Gearbox joint to allow the gear ratio to be adjusted dynamically, but the gearbox joint implementation wasn't behaving the way I expected. I was expecting it to behave like the ODE hinge joint implementation, which calls the helper function getHingeAngle with arguments: (child body, parent body, joint axis in body-fixed frame, initial relative rotation between bodies). By contrast, the gearbox joint had reversed the order of the bodies (reference body then child body), computed the joint axis in a global frame, and re-computed the relative body rotation (by calling dJointSetGearboxReferenceBody[12]) at each time step.

So this refactoring does the following:

  • Don't update relative rotations qrel[12] by calling dJointSetGearboxReferenceBody[12] at each timestep
  • Use body-fixed axis, not global
  • Reverse angle direction by switching relative bodies. This required reversing some arguments in other rotation calculations elsewhere in the file.

This should be a pure refactoring that doesn't change any behavior, but it will set the stage for an extension to this joint that I'd like to make. There is a gearbox joint test, and I've verified locally that it passes; hopefully CI agrees.

values.description:
Don't search for boost signals component since we aren't even using it, and it's removed from boost 1.69 (issue #2577).

I also added a couple missing changelog entries.

values.description:
issue #2531 - the blank grey window problem described in this issue seems to be related to [QTBUG-71044](https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-71044), which supposedly was fixed in Qt 5.12. I tried setting the env variable mentioned in the qt issue,`QT_MAC_WANTS_LAYER`, and found that it fixes the problem for gzclient. Tested on Mojave with Qt 5.12.

The changes in Scene.cc fixes camera orbit control on retina displays.
values.title: Mojave + Qt 5.12 gzclient fixes

summary.html:
issue #2531 - the blank grey window problem described in this issue seems to be related to QTBUG-71044, which supposedly was fixed in Qt 5.12. I tried setting the env variable mentioned in the qt issue,QT_MAC_WANTS_LAYER, and found that it fixes the problem for gzclient. Tested on Mojave with Qt 5.12.

The changes in Scene.cc fixes camera orbit control on retina displays.
